awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Lisa Piccirillo "Constructive techniques in low-dimensional topology." The host institution for the fellowship is Brandeis University, and the sponsoring scientist is Daniel Ruberman.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For the duration of the NSF Postdoctoral fellowship, the PIs primary research subject was 4-manifold topology. A manifold is a space which looks locally boring, but globally perhaps has complicated structure. A manifold is 2-dimensional if it locally looks like a piece of paper, and 3-dimensional if it locally looks like a foam block. Partly because 4-dimensional manifolds cannot be directly visualized, they remain poorly understood. To conceive of a 4-manifold, we often rely on studying level sets of the manifold, and trying to understand how they change over time. 

The primary subject of interest to the PI is how the study of 4-manifolds changes if you require the manifolds to be more regular (smooth) or allow them to be little more wild (topological).  The PI has several recent papers and preprints on this theme; these works have appeared for example in eg the Journal of Differential Geometry and Advances in Mathematics. 

The PI has also worked to provide platforms for young researchers to discuss their work. One of these, Trends in low-dimensional topology, was an online seminar cofounded by the PI during March 2020; during the depths of COVID this was the most attended online topology seminar series. Trends featured at least 2/3 early career speakers, and incorporated professional development events such as panels on postdoctoral applications and talks from topologists who work in industry. The PI also gave a recorded lecture series in summer 2021 which is freely available online; these lectures have already been used by many PhD students looking to enter the field. The PI has also been working to provide access to research mathematics more locally, by organizing a mathematics reading and mentoring program (DRP) at MIT; this program pairs undergraduate students with graduate student mentors to undertake a reading course in a subject not usually a part of the undergraduate cannon. This program includes coaching on learning to read and present mathematics in a conference environment.
